_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Two Evaporative Condensers; Intercooler; Low Pressure Receiver; Four Screw Compressors

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Birds Eye Foods is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard, Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations, Title 40 CFR Part 68, to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals.  

Through our Process Safety Managment Program, we promote overall plant, worker, and public safety.  The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances, as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, the program prevents accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, and avoids physical property damage.

Our safety program is applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or the on-site movement of such chemicals, or combinations of these activities.  Any group of vessels which are interconnected and separate vessels which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a single process.

Our safety programs prevent accidents by focusing on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and continually improved.  All rules are communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility. 

DESCRIPTION

The ammonia refrigeration process at the facility consists of various pumps, compressors, and condensers, that are used to change the state of NH3 from a gas to a liquid and is a closed loop system.  The motor and compressor are separate entities, and can be worked on should repairs be needed.  The ammonia is used in the freezing of vegetables.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

The general accident prevention program and ammonia-specific prevention steps were developed in accordance wit

h OSHA PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.110 and EPA Risk Management Program regulations in 40 CFR Part 68.  The key prevention steps at the facility consist of the following:

Employee Participation
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedures
Training
Contractor Requirements
Pre-startup Safety Review
Mechanical Integrity Audits
Hot Work Permits
Management of Change
Incident Investigation
Emergency Planning and Response
Compliance Audits

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

On September 3, 2008 at 8:27 p.m. a safety flow switch malfunctioned, indicating no water flow, and shut off Compressor CP106.  The pressure on the return line then increased (normal pressure is 52 PSI) and continued to build and exceed 150 PSI.  This caused a relief valve to actuate and alleviate the line pressure.  The leak was ventilated and some liquid ammonia that gathered on the roof was subsequently absorbed with floor dry.  

Total elapsed spill duration was estimated at 15 minutes.  Release amount is estimated at 500 pounds.  

Although the safety system performed properly, due to the atmospheric conditions, ammonia that was ventilated to the roof sunk in the air and entered through the facility's windows.  The plant's Emergency Response Team and the Waseca Fire Department responded.  The ammonia level, recorded at 8:35 p.m., was less than 7 PPM (OSHA Permissible Exposure Limit is 50 PPM).  23 employees were transported to the Emergency Room and received oxygen as a treatment.  All employees were released after receiving oxygen.  Bird's Eye Foods reported the incident to the Minnesota Duty Officer and The National Response Center.

As a result of the incident, Birds Eye Foods has responded by initiating administration and engineering controls on the ammonia system.  As an additional process control and mitigation system, a spill container with a small vent was installed on the roof over the relief line.  This preventative measure will ensure that any future ammonia discharged

to the relief line will not enter the facility in the same manner as it did on the September 3, 2008 incident.  Birds Eye Foods has also re-trained all ammonia operators, reviewed and revised all standard operating procedures, and revised maintenance procedures.  Relief valves are now annually inspected for proper operation in addition to the mandatory 5-year replacement rule.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Waseca facility's emergency response program is in accordance with OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plans (29 CFR 1910.38).  We have trained employees for emergency response and maintain a written emergency response plan.  This plan is coordinated with the Waseca Fire Department and annual drills for implementation of the emergency response plan are conducted at the facility.
